items.title: endcode is used intentionally
items.body:
In the dictionary.txt endcode is changed to encode.
However, endcode is often used intentionally: https://grep.app/search?q=endcode

I propose to kick it out of the dictionary or to prevent auto-fix.

items.title: Hidden directories
items.body:
Currently this generates some warnings

codespell --check-filenames --skip ./codespell_lib/data,./example/code.c,test_basic.py,*.pyc
##[warning]WARNING: Binary file: ./.git/index 

Which implies we're not ignoring hidden directories.

I don't know if we should or not? Should this follow --check-hidden so hidden files and directories are treated the same?

items.title: Filenames of empty files are not checked
items.body:
If a file has no content, `codespell --check-filenames` doesn't detect misspelled words in the filename:
```
$ codespell --version
1.18.dev0
$ touch abandonned
$ codespell --check-filenames
$ echo "foo" > abandonned
$ codespell --check-filenames
./abandonned: abandonned ==> abandoned
```

items.title: Inconsistent handling of hidden files
items.body:
If codespell is run on a directory, the contents of hidden files are checked:
```
$ codespell --version
1.18.dev0
$ codespell ./foo
./foo/.bar:1: abandonned ==> abandoned
```
but if codespell is pointed directly at a hidden file, it's ignored unless the `--check-hidden` option is used:
```
$ codespell ./foo/.bar
$ codespell --check-hidden ./foo/.bar
./foo/.bar:1: abandonned ==> abandoned
```
I would expect that if codespell is used without the `--check-hidden` option it should always ignore hidden files.

items.title: dictionary_rare missing
items.body: `codespell_lib/data/dictionary_rare.txt` is missing in the 1.17.0 PyPI source package causing a crash when all builtin dictionaries are used.

items.title: New wordings suggestion
items.body:
overwride->overwrite
constitue->constitute
constitues->constitutes
troublshooting->troubleshooting

items.title: How can I skip files when running codespell with pre-commit
items.body:
It seems that skipping files isn't working when codespell is run with pre-commit.

Here is our `.pre-commit-config.yaml`:

```yaml
repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell
    rev: v1.16.0
    hooks:
      - id: codespell
        args: [--skip="*.json"]
```

We tried the following syntaxes for the args:

```yaml
args: ["--skip", "*.json"]
args: ["--skip=*.json"]
args: ["-S", "*.json"]
args: [-S, *.json]
args: [--skip=*.json]
args: [--skip="*.json"]
```

However, when we pass in an ignore file, that does seem to work

```yaml
repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell
    rev: v1.16.0
    hooks:
      - id: codespell
        args: [-I, .codespellignore]
```

Is it possible to ignore some files when running codespell with pre-commit?

items.title: buggy exit status
items.body: The `codespell` command currently returns the number of spelling errors, but as an exit status, this has unspecified effects for large values (larger than 125). For instance, 256 will give a 0 exit status. While the number of spelling errors may be fine for the library, it has little interest for the command. The exit status should be either a fixed value (different from those used for other kinds of errors, such as "unrecognized arguments") or limited to some bound (125 or lower).

items.body: _Ned_ as a proper noun could be used in READMEs and code comments (as part of references/citations or mentioning points of contact inside the team or organization).

items.title: Incorrect suggestion: resoultion -> resolutions
items.body: However, it should be more like resoultion -> resolution (singular)

items.title: Ignore "\n"
items.body:
`codespell` is great, and we're using it to check our python source files in `pyvista`, but we're having issues with our jupyter notebooks.  For example: "\nTo" is recognized as a spelling error.

Is there any way to have `codespell` recognize and ignore line breaks?

items.title: 'ue' should be corrected to 'use' instead of 'due'
items.body:
I'm not sure this is fixable, since the word is so small it may throw off most reasonable metrics to pick one correction or the other. In particular, I assume that adding a character at the start or end of a misspelled sequence (which does not modify the sequence) may be scored higher than adding a character in the middle.

However, if no such heuristic is in place, then I'd suggest that in cases like this the most common word be scored higher ("use" is the [244th](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=word+frequency+of+use) most common English word, while "due" is [the 1331st](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=word+frequency+of+due)).

items.title: Could you please consider adding "reomve" as a version of "remove"?
items.body:
Looks like the following correction would be useful:

reomve -> remove

and it looks like "reomve" is not an existing word that would have any meaning.

items.title: RuntimeWarning: line buffering (buffering=1) isn't supported in binary mode with Python 3.8
items.body:
Running latest codespell under Python 3.8 results in the following warning:
```
.pyenv/versions/3.8.0/lib/python3.8/codecs.py:905: RuntimeWarning: line buffering (buffering=1) isn't supported in binary mode, the default buffer size will be used
  file = builtins.open(filename, mode, buffering)
```

This was introduced in Python 3.8 here:
https://bugs.python.org/issue32236

items.title: Heads up: Fossies.org offers optional source code misspelling check using <wait for it> codespell
items.body:
> Although misspelling corrections are not the most exciting issues and the spelling errors are rarely true code bugs but mostly contained in the comment and documentation parts they corrections can still improve the overall quality of a software project a bit.

> So since October 2019 Fossies offers optionally source code misspelling check reports using as basis the command line tool "codespell". The resulting analysis reports are currently per default not linked, on the one hand since they are essentially only of interest to the authors itself, on the other hand to avoid a taste of know-all-manner and snooping around. But if available they will be visible by directly accessing URLs like
```
  https://fossies.org/<folder>/<package>/codespell.html
```

source: https://fossies.org/features.html#codespell

items.title: Ignoring words that give a problem (whitelisting)
items.body:
I have a problem whitelisting some words (in version 1.16). Say I have the file
```
/*! \brief Include relation
 */
class IInclude
{
};
/*! \brief Include relation
 */
class aaccession
{
};
```
In that case I get the warnings when I just use `codespell`:
```
aa.h:3: IInclude  ==> include
aa.h:8: aaccession  ==> accession
```
but as we know in this case both are valid words I want to ignore them, so I run `codespell -L IInclude,aaccession` but I still get the message:
```
aa.h:3: IInclude  ==> include
```

How to do this properly?

Edit:
Also creating a file `whitelist.txt` with:
```
IInclude->Include
```
and running `codespell   -D whitelist.txt -D - -L IInclude,aaccession` does not bring a solution, still the same message with even a lowercase `i` for the `include`

items.title: The referer misspell
items.body:
Hi! Thanks for this great project.

I know "referer" technically is a misspell, however, it's a misspell that got used within the HTTP 1.0 RFC and is still to this day the name of a well-used HTTP field: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_referer

I'm guessing it should be on my responsibility to add it to the ignore file, but I thought I'd first bring this here to ask whether you wanted to allow the misspell. I don't know how common it is

items.title: Blank lines in dictionary aren't flagged by check-dictionary, cause crash
items.body:
Seen in codespell 1.15.0.dev0

If a blank line is introduced into the dictionary, `make check-dictionary` doesn't flag it as a problem, but when codespell is invoked, it crashes:

```
$ codespell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/codespell", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('codespell==1.15.0.dev0', 'console_scripts', 'codespell')()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 579, in _script_main
    return main(*sys.argv[1:])
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 625, in main
    build_dict(dictionary, misspellings, ignore_words)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 316, in build_dict
    [key, data] = line.split('->')
ValueError: need more than 1 value to unpack
```
I would expect 

1. The check-dictionary target to flag blank lines as an error
2. A make target that would strip blank lines out, along with any leading or trailing whitespace.

I have a Makefile patch ready; I'll submit a PR.

items.title: "cancelled" (british) -> "canceled" (american) was added to the dictionary

Maybe there's a way to check if british spellings are on the left hand side before merging PRs (in Travis), e.g. with a british word list with pre-existing rare words (for code) removed.

related to #103 

-----

https://www.grammarly.com/blog/canceled-vs-cancelled/

items.title: Ignore .svn and .git directories per default
items.body:
Hello,

I would like to ignore hidden directories like .svn or .git per default

Rationale:
* Yes, ignoring directories is possible via option -S, --skip or using xargs (see #60 and #99)
* Hidden files have to be enabled via option -H, --check-hidden
* However, hidden directories like .svn and .git are checked per default. This sounds inconsequent / illogical

items.title: Allow hidden files to be checked
items.body:
Looking at the code for some other stuff, I found hidden files are silently skipped by default:
https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell/blob/50bcf82833aaae8f99fc9b82d886c7191c117e0c/codespell_lib/_codespell.py#L331-L338
and
https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell/blob/f9f8d1fcca90c521baee52f397e2b3fc7f37f94c/codespell_lib/_codespell.py#L625-L626

As a user, I may want to spellcheck hidden files (e.g. my Travis file or other hidden config). It would be nice if it logged if it was skipping them, and add a command line option to scan them too.

items.title: Replacements that are themselves mistakes
items.body:
Some of the suggested replacements in dictionary.txt are listed as mistakes themselves.

Examples:
```
mimimise->minimise
minimise->minimize
orginal->orignal
orignal->original
passtime->pasttime
pasttime->pastime
shrinked->shrunk
srinkd->shrinked
srinked->shrinked
tranfering->transfering
transfering->transferring
```
Code to find these mistakes:
``` python
bad_words, new_words = {}, set()
lines = [line[:-1] for line in open('dictionary.txt')]

for line in lines:
    orig, replacements = line.split('->')
    bad_words[orig] = {word.strip() for word in replacements.split(',')}
    new_words.update(bad_words[orig])

highlight = {word for word in new_words if word in bad_words and word not in bad_words[word]}
for line in lines:
    if any(word in line for word in highlight):
        print(line)
```

items.title: Making the build reproducible
items.body:
Hi all,

There is an effort in Debian to ensure packages do build reproducible. Currently, codespell does fail in this regard, because it includes a [path in the help output](https://github.com/lucasdemarchi/codespell/blob/master/codespell_lib/_codespell.py#L223) (and therefore in the manpage). There is a proposed patch in Debian which just disables embedding the path in the output -- but before applying it, I wanted to ask people over here: what do you think?

Also, I'm much more in favor of getting this fixed here, upstream, instead of in Debian, downstream.

Thanks for your work,
cheers,
Georg

items.title: RFC: Remove statics->statistics from dictionary
items.body:
Reasons:  
1) many projects refer to static variables and static functions as 'statics' and will put all their static variables in that section.  
2) I have yet to encounter `statics` as a legit misspelling for `statistics`  
3) I often find that I need to put 'statics' in to an ignore list aka whitelist for many projects.

```
  File "/home/beast/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 557, in _script_main
    return main(*sys.argv[1:])
  File "/home/beast/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 636, in main
    bad_count += parse_file(fname, colors, summary)
  File "/home/beast/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/codespell_lib/_codespell.py", line 532, in parse_file
    'RIGHTWORD': crightword, 'REASON': creason})
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character '\xed' in position 88: ordinal not in range(128)
```

items.title: Feature: CI test to sort any submitted corrections to dictionary.txt
items.body: As @pabs3 does from time to time manually, have this process automated.

items.title: Feature: CI test for duplicate entries
items.body: When a PR is submitted, the test should search to see if the PR is duplicating any entries and report.

items.title: Feature: CI test for missing '->' in dictionary.txt
items.body: Similar to #303 but incorporate a CI regex test on `dictionary.txt` for any missing `->` strings. The regex: `^(.(?!(->)))*$` to use.

items.title: Feature: CI test for missing commas in dictionary.txt
items.body:
In #302 I mention a regex that tests `dictionary.txt` for missing commas in multi-answer typos. I suggest we have a CI test that executes ` ^(?=\w+->(?!\w+$)(?:\w+, )*\w+(?!,)$).+` to test for missing commas and reports it clearly. 
```
amin->main, disabled because of var names
clas->class, disabled because of name clash in c++
cmo->com, disabled due to lots of false positives
gonna->going to, disabled because one might want to allow informal spelling
pass-thru->pass-through, pass through, passthrough
pass-trough->pass-through, pass through, passthrough
```

The above regex is intelligent enough to distinguish the above examples not as false positives:
https://regex101.com/r/Mz4piI/1

items.title: Have a 'grep -C' like feature which shows the context in which the typo is in
items.body:
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9081/grep-a-file-but-show-several-surrounding-lines#9083
This kind of functionality would be awesome in codespell since many times the context the typo is displayed in is not enough (1 sentence context is not enough sometimes to understand the problem fully). 
`grep -A <number>` returns the `<number>` of lines **before** the match
`grep -B <number>` returns the `<number>` of lines **after** the match
`grep -C <number>` returns the `<number>` of lines **before AND after** the match

items.title: Pass specific words to -I flag as parameters instead of needing to use a file
items.body:
Thanks to @thdot per #100 we can now use `-I <file name>` to ignore certain words. Each word needs to be on a separate line in the file. That is great when there is a place to save a whitelist file to so codespell can read it. 

But say we were in a [Buildbot](https://github.com/buildbot/buildbot) environment, an automated testing framework, where we've setup codespell as a unit test... and so there isn't an easy possibility to save a whitelist file somewhere? Or another scenario, we're trying to quickly filter out a ginormous list of false positives from a codespell result, one needs to open their favorite editor and add each word on a separate line and link said file. It's not the most efficient. 

It would be then useful to then have the the ability to pass the whitelisted words sequentially ex. `codespell -I 'nto,ans,pres,ot,amin'` 
Thoughts?

items.title: proposal: proposal: remove or assign lower visibility to `dum`
items.body:
I get a lot of false positives with `dum` over multiple FOSS projects. I say we get rid of it or do the same as we did in #163 
Thoughts?

items.title: proposal: remove or assign lower visibility to `iff`
items.body:
Currently codespell dictionary.txt has `iff->if` as an entry. 
Iff in mathematics means `if and only if` see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/iff
I get a ton of false positives with it. 
I suggest we to either remove it or designate it as 
`iff->if, disabled due to a valid mathematical concept` or something...
Thoughts?

items.title: How to install the most bleeding edge version of codespell via apt-get ?
items.body:
Context #139 
I'm wanting to install the most up to date dev version of codespell via apt-get. I want this because in the travisci sequence `addon:` is [the first](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build#The-Build-Lifecycle). 
I'd like to run the equivalent of `pip3 install --user --upgrade git+https://github.com/lucasdemarchi/codespell.git` as an `apt-get` command...how do I do this?

items.title: codespell: command not found
items.body:
Installed with a raspberry pi running Raspian Stretch and I'm getting the error:

> bash: codespell: command not found

trying to run the following command:

> codespell -h

I ran 

> pip install codespell

and the build was successful and I made sure to check in ~/.local/bin to see if codespell was in there and it was indeed located there.

Any ideas?

items.title: How to use codespell to test a project's incoming PRs via Continuous Integration (ex. TravisCI)
items.body:
Has anyone seen or used codespell as a unit test that gets triggered in TravisCI when a new PR submitted ?

Downstream ticket: https://freecadweb.org/tracker/view.php?id=3205

items.title: Integrate QGIS spelling.dat list entries in to dictionary.txt
items.body:
[QGIS](http://github.com/QGIS/QGIS) has a typo detection tool in their repo with a list that they have created for well known typos. It lives at: https://github.com/qgis/QGIS/blob/master/scripts/spell_check/spelling.dat
Notice though they do prefer British English spelling. 

I was trying to write a script that would diff out all non-duplicate entries so I could add them to codespell. But I've been hitting snags so I opened up this issue.

items.title: Feature: update dictionary.txt without waiting for the next version
items.body: An idea to add functionality that checks for the latest dictionary.txt file on GitHub and downloads it if needed.

items.title: Would it be possible to release a new minor version?
items.body: So as to include the bdc95edd79459c88d9b45e860e415750b31c33e8 and other dictionary additions ?

items.title: What does 'disable due to \n' mean?
items.body:
Codespell result looked like: 
`./App/AreaPyImp.cpp:163: nTo  ==> not  | disable due to \n`

The code in question:
```
"\nTo ensure no stray abortion is left in the previous operation, it is advised to manually clear\n"
```

items.title: Update PyPi please?
items.body:
The version of [codespell on pypi](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/codespell) is 1.9.2, which is almost 9 months old (and doesn't have support for loading multiple dictionaries).

Could we have a new release please? :-)

items.title: how to ignore directories ?
items.body:
`codespell.py -d -q 3 --skip="*.po,*.ts,src/3rdParty/*"`
doesn't ignore searching src/3rdParty/

items.title: codespell always has an exit value of zero
items.body:
Even when there are spelling errors, codespell will exit with a 0. That makes it hard to fail a build step if the spell check fails.

I think it would be nice to exit with a value different than 0 in case of errros. Maybe optional behind a flag to not change the behaviour for existing users.

items.title: [wishlist] would be great if it is able to generate a patch
items.body: When there're full of typo, a directly generated patch will be great!

items.title: ImportError: No module named 'codespell_lib'
items.body:
I using codespell on scrutinizer which is a ci

unfortunately it doesn't work

My commands are:

```
pip install codespell

Collecting codespell
  Downloading codespell-1.9.2.tar.gz (45kB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 51kB 4.2MB/s 
25hBuilding wheels for collected packages: codespell
  Running setup.py bdist_wheel for codespell ... 25l- done
25h  Stored in directory: /home/scrutinizer/.cache/pip/wheels/20/42/eb/32e6da9b97cf208b6e9cecaaf9c08e324f1826a136c721637f
Successfully built codespell
Installing collected packages: codespell
Successfully installed codespell-1.9.2
```

if I then try to run the command with something like:

```
python ../bin/codespell.py app/Config/core.php
The command exited with code 1.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "../bin/codespell.py", line 6, in 
    import codespell_lib
ImportError: No module named 'codespell_lib'
```

it doesn't work untill I add a full path to PYTHONPATH which I dont think is expected

items.title: Makefile is broken
items.body: The makefile is no longer working, since there is no longer a codespell.py

items.title: codespell.py does nothng if [fileN] is not specified
items.body: Previously running `codespell` without file parameter starts the check. Now `codespell.py` does nothing. The behavior should stay the same as before - if file/dir argument is not specefied then current directory should be used as a default parameter.

items.title: README: outdated license notice
items.body:
README says:

> The Python script `codespell.py` is available with the following terms:

But currently `codespell.py` is just a thin wrapper over `codespell_lib`, with little to no creativity.
This sentence should probably read something like this:

> The Python code is available with the following terms:

items.title: There is no ./codespell.py
items.body:
README says:

> Check usage with `./codespell.py -h`

But there is no `./codespell.py` (unless you cd into `bin`, in which case the command doesn't work either).

`codespell.py` was moved from `.` to `bin` in b400e4250d7342b76e361cfcf738da6f65fee035, but I don't understand why. The commit message is enigmatic.

items.title: ImportError: No module named codespell_lib
items.body:
I downloaded the script and ran it as:

```
$ ./vendor/lucasdemarchi/codespell/bin/codespell.py -h
```

but it gives:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./vendor/lucasdemarchi/codespell/bin/codespell.py", line 6, in <module>
    import codespell_lib
ImportError: No module named codespell_lib
```

If I copy codespell.py one directory up and run that, it works.

items.title: how to add "wrong" words to dictionary?
items.body:
i want to add 'churchs' as a _good_ word (a shoebrand!)
to my private dictionary, but codespell always want
to correct it with churchs->churches

what is the proposed way to do this?

items.title: Python2 support
items.body: Would the devs be interested in me adding support for Python2? I've worked on a number of packages with support for Python2 and Python3, so I don't expect it would be too bad.

items.title: please set returncode according to file(s) OK or not
items.body:
no errors = 0 and errors found should give >0.

for now it always succeeds:

```
user@box:~# ./codespell.py -i 0 $FILE
(several mistakes)
user@box:~# echo $?
0
```

but i exspect e.g. '1'

items.title: Ignoring directories
items.body:
Hello,

I would like to ignore everything that's in (or anywhere below) a specific directory. This currently doesn't seem to be supported, though.
Would you mind implementing it?

Thanks for the useful tool!

items.title: isnt is a command in CoffeScript
items.body: `isnt` is a command in CoffeScript and therefore no spelling mistake for `.coffee` (or `.jade`) files. Is it possible to add something like whitelists depending on the file type?

items.title: Any change of adding this to PyPi?
items.body: Our project installs tools via pip to keep things nice and clean and virtualenv friendly--It would be great if codespell was added to Pypi.

items.title: Codespell should ignore empty files (and not print error/warning).
items.body:
One minor change in behavior that could be made: Right now, if a file is empty it prints something like:

`ERROR: Could not detect encoding: ./__init__.py`

It should probably just pass over these files and not print anything.

items.title: Where in the documentation does it say Python 3 is a requirement?
items.body:
Please update README.md.  On a CentOS 6.6 system (python 2.6.6), I received the following message after attempting to execute codespell.py:

$ python codespell.py
  File "codespell.py", line 146
    file=sys.stderr)
        ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

$ ./codespell.py
/usr/bin/env: python3: No such file or directory

Also, in the Usage section, it should be './codespell.py -h' and not './codespell -h'.

items.title: make check is failing
items.body: In the latest release (1.7) `make check` is failing.

items.title: manpage
items.body:
Hi Lucas!

Thank you for providing codespell, I use it almost every day.

I recognized that there is no manpage for this tool. It would be nice to have one. However Paul Wise hinted that there might occur inconsistencies between the manpage and the --help option.

See here: https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=779900

What do you think about adding a `git help` like approach for --help and the manpage?

Greetings
Peter

items.title: How to handle two correct spellings?
items.body: Currently the dictionary changes `modeled` to `modelled`. However, both spellings are correct, though `modeled` is preferred. Is the best way to handle this to remove the line, or to reverse it so that the preferred spelling, `modeled`, is used?

items.title: "codespell | less" should not use ASCII codes
items.body: In case if output of 'codespell' is redirected (e.g. to file or to pager) then it should avoid using ASCII color codes

items.title: incorrect entry for guarrenteed
items.body:
This entry in dictionary.txt is wrong:

guarrenteed->guarenteed

It should be:

guarrenteed->guaranteed

items.title: Is it possible to detect wrong spelled words like this:
Is it possible to add dictionary entries like this?
items.body:
multy-thread->multithread

Currently codespell does not support these kind of entries.

Thanks  and best regards

Martin Ettl

items.title: Codespell does not work with an empty line in dictionary
items.body:
Codespell does not work with an empty line in the dictionary. This error can easily reproduced by added an empty line into the dictionary.txt -file an run codespell. The output will be:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/codespell.py", line 526, in <module>
    sys.exit(main(*sys.argv))
  File "/usr/bin/codespell.py", line 473, in main
    build_dict(args[0])
  File "/usr/bin/codespell.py", line 265, in build_dict
    [key, data] = line.split('->')
ValueError: need more than 1 value to unpack

If this is an intentional behaviour, feel free to close this issue.

Best regards

Martin Ettl

items.title: unable to run codespell.py on debian lenny with python 3.2.1
items.body:
$ python3 --version
Python 3.2.1

Here is the traceback:

$./codespell.py dictionary.txt dictionary.txt 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./codespell.py", line 526, in <module>
    sys.exit(main(*sys.argv))
  File "./codespell.py", line 473, in main
    build_dict(args[0])
  File "./codespell.py", line 264, in build_dict
    for line in f:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.2/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
    return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 3170: ordinal not in range(128)

What do you suggest?

Many thanks

Martin
